Ano ka ba, maging proud ka! Para 'yang pagkakaroon ng aking fighting style at kay Mitsuo sa isang tao.
Talagang nakakatakot iyon.
"Kailan ka uuwi?" tanong niya.
Hmm, wala na para sa linggong ito.
Bakit may paghusga?
Medyo um-okay na rin ang pakiramdam ko matapos makatulog at makakain. Nasaan kaya siya?
Bwesit na bata.
"Kumusta siya?" tanong ko.
"Binali ko ang kanyang braso," bulong niya, na nagdulot ng pouting mula sa akin. "Aksidente."
"Anong ginagawa mo?" tanong niya ng mahimbing, ang kanyang mga mata ay nakapikit pa.
"Ah, shit, nakalimutan kong kikitain ko si Keith," sabi niya sa ilalim ng kanyang buntong hininga.
Napaka sinungaling.
Ang mga tao ay nilalang ng pagbabago at sa mga nabubuhay, mayroon silang pinakamahusay na kakayahan upang umangkop.

Sa pagtatapos ng ika-19 na siglo, ang mga natatanging uri ng tao na ito ay kilala sa kanilang sariling lahi bilang Erityians—isang pangalang karapat-dapat sa kanilang mga pinagmulan at kakayahan—mga anak ng espesyal na dugo.
Sadyang nakikisama sa mga normal na tao, sila ay nagligtas at sumira ng mga sibilisasyon at buhay.
Pagod na pagod, inabot ni Emiko ang kanyang anak sa mga bisig ng nakatatanda. "A-aking anak . . . ibigay mo sa akin ang aking anak . . ."
"Halimaw!" sumigaw ng babae siya habang sinubukan niyang umalis sa bahay, ngunit mas mabilis ang lalaki.
Hindi mo kailangang pag-usapan ang kakaibang katangian ng ating mga mata sa sinuman. Narinig mo ba ako?
Ngunit ang mga taong iyon ay may din ng poot sa atin, hindi ba? Bakit hindi ko magagawa ang pareho, kapatid?
Alam kong mahirap, pero sinabi sa atin ng ama na huwag silang kamuhian. Ang ama ay isang mabait na tao, at gusto niyang maging ganun tayo.
Sobra na at ang mga ganid at masama ay mapapakinabangan ito. Ang ama ay mabait, ngunit naiv din.
"Bilisan mo," sabi niya, pinutol ang usapan ni Ryō. "Umalis ka na sa lugar na ito."
Ama! Bakit ka—
"Ama," tawag niya. "May mga tao . . . may mga tao na papunta dito."
Ang katotohanan ay, palagi kong kinamumuhian ang mga tao, ngunit ayaw kong ibahagi mo ang parehong damdamin dahil hindi lahat sa kanila ay masama.
Kahit gaano kahirap, mabuhay nang maayos, Shō, Ryō. Mabuhay at patunayan na hindi kasalanan ang mabuhay dahil tayo ay iba.
"A-anong nangyari—" Tumigas ang katawan ni Ryō nang naaalala ang nangyari bago siya nawalan ng malay. "Ama!"
Ama! Hindi!
"Ama!" sigaw ni Ryō habang tumakbo siya patungo kay Shotarō.
"Hindi natin maaring ipakita ito sa kanila," sabi ni Shō.
Marahil talagang mga halimaw tayo. Ang mga mata ng ama. Ang iyong mga mata. Maging ang misteryo sa likod ng pagkamatay ng ina at ng ating angkan.
"At ano kung ganun, kapatid?" sagot niya. "Sa tingin mo ba, tinatrato silang iba sa atin? Ang mga taong iba sa normal ay palaging itinuturing na mga outcast. Mga kakaiba. Mga halimaw."
Anong . . . anong ginawa mo, Ryō?
Ipinagpatuloy ko ang hindi natapos na negosyo ng ama.
Ryo, sabihin mo sa akin . . . ilan ang . . .
Pumatay lamang ako ng mga umatake sa atin.
Kailangan nating umalis sa nayon na ito, Ryō,
Sinabi nilang ang ating angkan ay dati nang isang marangal na lahi ng mga samurais.
Dapat tayong tahimik na umalis sa bahay,
Huwag mong ibabad ang iyong mga kamay sa higit pang dugo, kapatid,
Ngunit paano? Napapalibutan na tayo.
Hindi ko hayaang mamatay ka dito.
Tingnan mo ang mundo sa sarili mo. Nandito ako, at ibabalik ko ang kinuha nila sa atin: ang dangal ng ating angkan, ang ating kayamanan, at ang pagmamalaki ng ama. Paalam, kapatid.
Pangako, kahit ang mga diyos ng kamatayan ay hindi makakapigil sa akin. Para sa ama at para sa iyo, magiging isa ako sa kanila.
Sa ating tribo, ang mga pangalan ng mga patay ay iniiwasan, ngunit ibinigay sa akin ng aking mga magulang ang kanyang pangalan dahil gusto nila akong mawala.
"Ishida . . ." bulong ng bata habang ang kanyang mga mata ay kumikislap sa kasiyahan.
Hindi mo maaring protektahan ang iyong sarili sa pamamagitan lamang ng pagtakas, lalo na kapag laging nakatago ang panganib. Minsan, kailangan mong maging matibay.
"hindi . . ." umiiyak siya.
"Kitang-kita?" ngumiti siya. "Wala kang dapat ikatakot."
"Kaya't hindi mo na kailangang itago ang iyong mga mata," dagdag niya.
Hindi ko pa naranasan ang tag-init, ngunit ang init ng iyong presensya ay dapat na ganito. Mula ngayon, ikaw ay si Natsue.
Hinawakan niya ang kaniyang kamay at ngumiti. "Masaya ako . . . salamat . . ."
Paalam, kapatid,
Babalik ako, at makikita kita muli.
"Pakiusap!" ang sumunod na lalaki ay nagmamakaawa.
Ngayon ay humihingi ka ng awa.
Pakiusap, may pamilya ako—
Masyado nang huli para humingi ka ng tulong sa mismong bagay na inalis mo sa amin.
Alis, o papatayin ko siya!
Tatayo ka lang ba diyan buong gabi?
Ipag-patawad, panginoon.
M-mangyaring patawarin, ginoo, ito—
Kahit na may kapangyarihang ganito, ang isang tulad ko ay mananatiling burakumin hanggang sa kamatayan.
Ganito ang kapalaran ng mga ipinanganak sa pinakamababang uri.
Paumanhin, ginoo,
Isang araw, ang mga dakilang kapangyarihan ng mga natural na elemento ay ipapasa sa mga karapat-dapat, tulad ng kung ano ang inisip ng ating dakilang ninuno na si Czeslav.
Lumayo ka,
"Yllka," mahinang tawag ng kanyang ina, ikinulong ang kanyang mukha. " Tumingin ka sa akin. Nasaktan ka ba?
Hawakan ito ng mabuti!
Sila ay nag-mamarcha dito! Maghanda!
Susunugin mo rin ang gubat!
Patayin ang apoy!
"Ang iyong mga mata," bulong niya. "Naging mas magaan ang kulay."
Ayos, Yllka,
Maging isang espion . . . mahirap ba?
Dapat may sapat sila na lakas upang makapasok at makatakas mula sa mga base; at may talino upang mangolekta ng impormasyon at magsagawa ng kontra-impormasyon laban sa mga kaaway.
Bakit pinabayaan ka ng bansang iyong pinaglilingkuran nang matagpuan ka ng mga kaaway?
Ngunit hindi ako normal, di ba? Bakit? Ako ba ay sinumpa, ina?
Aking anak, makinig ka sa akin. Ang pagiging iba ay maaaring mahirap, ngunit hindi ibig sabihin na ikaw ay sinumpa. Marahil isa ito sa kalooban ng ating mga ninuno.

Ang isang bukas na isipan na ay papaboran. Ang sangkatauhan ay patuloy na umuunlad, kung gusto man natin o hindi, at ang mga nais, ay maaaring tumanggap ng kamalayan ng mga diyos at ang kapangyarihan ng mga natural na puwersa.
Kung makita mo ang iyong ama, sabihin mong nauna na ako.
Maging pinakadakilang espion na nagbigay ng liwanag sa mundo.
At marahil . . . ako rin ay nasa dulo ng linya.
Matutulungan kita, Ama. Lumabas na tayo—
Talagang ikinalulungkot ko na pinagawa ko ito sa iyo, ngunit ikaw ang kinakailangan. Ito lamang ang paraan upang iligtas tayong dalawa.
Mukha namang nagulat ang lalaki, ngunit sumilay ang nakakagaan na ngiti sa kanyang mukha. "Sabi ko na. Talagang magkahawig tayo. Ang pangalan ay Hagen," pagpapakilala niya.
Hagen, sumama ka sa akin. Tayo ang magiging mga tagapangalaga at tagapagtanggol ng mga lihim ng mundo.
Naging mabilis ang pangyayari, at bago niya ito maunawaan, ang ilang mga sibilyan ay . . .
Ano ang ginawa ko? Nasaan si Ishida? Ano ang . . .
"I-Ito'y . . ." tiningnan niya si Shinji, na nananatiling hindi makapaniwala.
Nagngingitngit siya sa balita.
Isang eksaktong suntok, iniisip niya habang inasinta ang leeg, ngunit agad na napigilan ang kanyang plano ng mga samurai sa kanyang tabi.
"Sino ka?!"
Patayin siya!
Maaaring ikaw ay naging dakilang alalay.
Ilabas mo ako rito!
H-halimaw! Patayin siya! Ngayon na!
Ngayon, buhay mo ang kabayaran.
Sabihin ang iyong pangalan at layunin, mananakop.
Ang mga ilog ay nasa aming teritoryo,
Ngunit, Pinuno—
Kailangan kong bumaba rito,
Paano mo ito nagawa, Pinuno?
Bakit dito?!

Sapat na ang titig ni Edda para patahimikin ang crew. Ako ang magdadala lamang kila Hagen at Morgan. Ang iba sa inyo ay dapat mabuhay kung hindi magiging maganda ang kalalabasan. Ngayon, umalis na kayo!
Ito ba talaga ang gitna ng mundo?
Napangiti agad si Edda nang makita ang mga taong sakay. "Ang mga may berdeng mata ay minsang lumalahok."
Sa wakas,Ikinalulugod kong makilala ka.
Patawarin ako kung ako'y nahuli,
Ngunit ang iyong kasama ay tila may galit sa amin.
Ishida, tandaan mo ang iyong hatol,
Nag-aalala lamang ako sa kaligtasan ng aking panginoon.
"Kapatid," tugon nito na may bakas ng galit sa kanyang mukha.
Gusto ko nang makauwi sa lalong madaling panahon.
Ang iyong mga ahente ay magaling na kahit sa pinakamalayong lupain ay nagagawang makapasok,
Tinikop ni Yllka ang kaniyang kamao.May mga mananakop ba sa ating mga nayon? Ano ang iyong binabalak?
Ang mga kapangyarihan na taglay namin ay maaaring baguhin ang mundo, sabi ni Edda.
Ang mga ito'y kamangha-mangha ngunit nakakatakot, kaya pinili kong manatili sa anino. Sa tingin ko, ginawa mo rin ito.
Napakapangit ng mga tao.
Ang dati naming malawak na tahanan ay nabawasan sa ilang nayon na nagkakandirit sa isang bundok.
Ang ginawa lang nila ay kumuha ng mga likas na yaman at manakop ng mga lupain.
Hindi ko sila pinagkakatiwalaan.
"Sapat na 'yang kalokohan, kapatid," sigaw ni Ryo
Ang kabaitan ay hindi basta ibinibigay kanino man, at wala akong maibibigay sa mga taong gusto mong protektahan mula sa kapahamakan.
Paano kung magtayo tayo ng isang bagong nasyon?
Sa halip na magtago sa mundo, maaari tayong lumikha ng ligtas na lugar para sa mga katulad natin, at mula rito, maaari nating pagmasdan ang mundo mula sa malayo.
Gaya ng inaasahan ko. Walang saysay ang pagpupulong na ito.
Ayokong makipagsabwatan sa mga taong hindi sumasang-ayon sa aking mga paniniwala. Bukod dito, mayroon na akong lupaing pinamumunuan.
Pakiusap, Ryō. Pwede ba tayong mag-usap?
Paalam. Sana'y hindi na tayo magkita muli.
Hindi maganda ang nangyari, Pinuno,
Dapat na rin tayong bumalik, Pinuno,
Hindi ligtas dito.
Umuwi na tayo.
Ayoko sa totoong taglamig,
Hey, mag-ingat!
Madudulas ka!
Maraming salamat,
Kumusta ang tribo ng Huntres? Narinig ko na may mga grupo ng mga mang-uudyok na muling lilitaw,
Kayong tatlo ay nahuli.
Lagi kang usisero, di ba?
Dahil ang aking tribo ay isang ahensya ng katalinuhan, sa tingin mo ba na mas kakaiba kung hindi ko alam?
Ngumiti si Rainie. "Oh, oo, pero unti-unti ko nang sinasalo ang ilan sa kanyang mga gawain."
"Ayos," sabi ni Krystal. "Hindi magiging opisyal ang summit na ito kung hindi lahat ay pinuno."
Ang poot ay isang bagay na hindi madaling mapawi. Sigurado akong alam nating lahat 'yan.
Ngunit umaasa ako na magawa nating tahakin ang daan patungo sa pangarap na 'yan, kahit papaano, At napatuloy si Rainie.
Natahimik lahat ng ilang segundo, ngunit ang tawa ni Nel ang bumasag sa tensiyon. Bagaman ikaw ang pinakabata at tila mahiyain, may kakaibang husay ka sa mga salita.
"Hindi na ako makapaghintay na ikaw ang maging lider. Mas mature ka kaysa sa isang ito".
Sabihin mo na lang na ikaw ay madaling magalit, sabi ni Nel.
Isang ngiti ang lumabas sa kanyang labi nang makita niya ang tatlo.
"Your tibialis anterior is damaged."
"Sadly, he's in the West."
"Sorry."
"It's just a joke."
"It's nice to see you again, Rainie."
Uh oh. I smell trouble.
Then all of a sudden, I sensed an incredible amount of pressure and all of us summoned and drew our weapons, pointing them to each other, then the table and chairs were suddenly frozen.
"No. You sound like your dad—a leader."
That place is too quiet that I tend to hear a lot of buzzing and humming, plus the tension in the surrounding is too high.
"Of course. Her team successfully infiltrated the Shinigami's base and retrieved her comrades' eyes."
"That's great."
"I see. I guess there's no need to worry about you."
"Thanks for this, by the way. It warms me up since we're living on a cold place."
"Nice. I didn't even notice it," then he tossed it to Reiji and he caught it.
"That it's dangerous. She's worried about us."
"Don't let go," Hiro said. And the next thing I knew, the Black Dimension was already closing and I saw the pain in his expression.
"You almost died."
She lost her husband and dearest friends, and she didn't see her son for fifteen years.
"What did you do? Two of your fatal points are in dire state."
"N-no way. My eyes are not that..."
They are in trouble.
I can hear the two of them cursing inside their head while heading to the building in front of them.
I smiled triumphantly. I fulfilled my role.
But I don't think I can last any longer because all of them lunged at me.
These Shinigamis are going to kill me.
"What the hell is this creepy feeling?"
"One more word and I'll behead you."
"If you could, old hag."
"You're going with us, whether you like it or not."
I have a bad feeling about this.
"Go all out. Erase this place where she suffered a lot."
"Chase him!"
"I won't let you touch him," I whispered as I released the arrow from the bow.
It hit the back of the Shinigami and Darwin looked at me with a proud expression.

As I was looking at my father taking down the building, I felt a sense of relief and sadness. Seeing his actions, I know that he wanted to do this after all this time. He wanted to erase this place where my mother suffered.
"Yeah. I'm scared to know the truth."
"I really admire you, Mama. You're so strong. And even if nobody's talking about you here because they said you were a curse, you will always be my hero. It's just sad that you're not here anymore."
"She died in his arms."
"I don't know," he said and I saw the sadness in his eyes. "These past few months, I've been recollecting some unfamiliar memories."
"But remembering is just as worse as forgetting."
"His cries filled the place."
"Still unstable but we're recovering. Thanks to all of you."
"Wow. Thank you, Darwin. I'm going to use this."
I'm glad that it didn't turn out that way. I still have him at my side.
"I'm back, Vince," I whispered as I caressed his grave.
His death still haunts me and gives me nightmares.
"Even though a lot of things happened, I'm glad that I still have the both of you," I said while keeping my tears from falling. "So please...don't you ever dare to die on me, too."
Coming back here and being with them made those memories vivid. If I could only rewind the time we were the happiest... If I could only stop the time once again...

However, after hearing his thoughts, I felt sad and hurt because he's starting to remember the war fifteen years ago when he was just a one-year old baby. Maybe subconsciously, he pushed them away to the depths of his mind but the second war triggered them to resurface.
"He chose to protect you. He did everything to save our future so instead of being sorry, be thankful to your father. Will you do that for me, Nathan?"
My tears fell as I remember our happy moments together and I feel miserable because all these memories keep coming back...but he never does. And he never will.
"Tss. I want to get out of this place immediately. Why do I have to be with these people? I'm going to kick that old fart's ass when I get back."
"N-No, sir."
"Damn you, old fart, are you playing with me?!"
"Well, being curious isn't bad."
Wow. That's handy but a bit sad. Will he also forget people after a long time? Will his memories fade away?
"You look so confident and calculating outside but deep inside, you're anxious and insecure of yourself."
"Sir Eiichi!" I squeaked and he just smiled at me.
Beyond that, wild and vicious creatures freely roam around to serve as our external protection from unwelcomed visitors. However, we are not exempted from their attacks.
Without any warning, something monstrous charged towards me.
I immediately jumped to the branches of the tree beside me and the creature banged its head straight to the bark. The tree shook tremendously and I almost fell directly to that thing.
His low growl made my skin crawl and when the moonlight illuminated the surroundings, my stomach tightened due to the creature's unsightly appearance.

Possessing a broad and long husk, it looks like a boar but the size of lion. Its jaws and teeth are those of a shark while its body is covered with sharp hairs. Looking at it for a few seconds made me nauseous and panic started to engulf my senses.
Just when I thought that one monster is enough to scare the heck out of me, two . . . three . . . six . . . six more appeared and surrounded us. Terror dominated my mind and body.
"Shit, I said stop it!" Mitsuo shouted and he kneeled so that I can see him. "These creatures can smell fear and they are attracted to it. If you don't want to attract more of them, calm yourself!"
"Let me hold this for a while," I breathed. "Please." He stayed silent but after a few seconds, he moved and positioned his back in front of me.
"Him?" A taunting smile formed on her lips.
Hearing the Council of Elders made my skin crawl. They are a group of advisers and counselors who help the leaders with their decisions and rules.
Their loyalty to the tribe is absolute but that's also the reason why they are perceived as cold and heartless.
They will do anything to protect the Senshins and this place, even if it poses harm and danger to others.

"But I am not someone you can follow carelessly," he said with a serious tone and I can feel the goosebumps all over my body. The first thing that came into my mind is to escape but I don't want to be seen as a coward. Not by him.

We both went quiet after that. I don't know what happened but after a few seconds, we smiled at each other. And this time, I know that something has changed between us.

I was dead serious about that but he stared at me, as if I just said something ridiculous, and after a few seconds, he burst out laughing.

"Forget about me," he said and I felt a twinge in my chest.

I don't care. If you can't live with me, then I'll let you live in my memories.

Maybe it's because I was used to forget people every now and then that I thought everyone would also be like that. But you know what? If I could live another life, I'd still choose to remember you. Even if my own memories were erased, as long as you're still inside my head, it would be enough.'
"I will always remember you, Nathalie."

"If . . . if I'm allowed to voice out my wish . . . then please . . . please help me see the end of this. I . . . I want to avenge my clan," she whimpered in her inner voice. "I want to be free from this excruciating revenge already. Please . . . help me."
"It's okay now."
"Wait, don't tell me you'll use it to her?"
"Without her consent?"
"D-Daddy . . ." Kana whimpered.
"Survive, child. You have to. I'm sorry."
"It's okay. Don't be scared. Everything will be okay. Just close your eyes. I'll be here."
"I won't be here anymore when you wake up. I'm sorry for leaving you alone. But please, be strong. Continue protecting your life, even if you're by yourself. I love you."
"Then this makes things easier," Hiroshi added.
"I've rested enough," she muttered. "It's time to get my revenge."
"I need to find that Elite. He's the one who killed my father."
"Kana, the Elite of the Reaper you fought that night was Takeshi," I said and her eyes vehemently reflected rage. "And we know how to find him."

"I don't know his motives or why he had to involve himself in this mess, but one thing is for sure, he shares the same crime of murdering hundreds of innocent people and I will never forgive him for that."
"So, you can finally fight without holding back," I commented while we were running through the buildings. She smiled. "I guess."
"Yeah. I can feel its presence. Be careful. The Black Dimension might open anytime."
"I'll make you pay for your crimes, murderer," she growled.
"No, kid. You will pay for the crime of your clan. You will tell me about the heir. That's—!"
"You . . ." Kana snarled as she glared at the humdrum. "You were there. You, too, killed everyone!"
"Where are you?" I mumbled. "It's getting dangerous here."
"What the hell are you saying?" Kana grumbled. "Assist who? The person who killed⁠ —"
Damn it!
"Behind you!" I alerted as I felt the opening of the Black Dimension near Kana.
"You should've told us first if there are any explosives in the vicinity, you humdrum," Kana growled as she glared at Ariel who was still in his knees.
"I'm sorry for using her face. I had to survive. Don't worry, the end is near. You won't see this face after this."
"Kana, please calm down," I pleaded
How can I?! That face . . . that was my mother's! How could you use—!
"No!" he bellowed as my dagger grazed his cheek. "I've had enough of your silly plays!"
"You have to do better than that, brat—!"
"It's okay. Everything will be okay," he softly said while turning his head to our direction.
Ariel smiled. "Yes. This is the only way."
"I . . . got my . . . revenge . . ." he said in whispers. "I . . . will . . . finally be . . . with my . . . ffamily. S-sorry for what . . . I did . . ."
"If only . . . I have known . . . your clan . . . before those . . . scums . . . if only . . ."
"We're Senshins," I said. "Erityians aren't only the Shinigamis. I'm sorry if you've been through hell because of them."

"I . . . see . . . t-thank you . . . for telling . . . me . . ." His gaze shifted to Kana again. "And . . . tthank . . . you . . . for your . . . kindness. Your parents . . . and clan . . . would be so proud . . ."
"I know," she sobbed. "I know."
"It's . . . okay . . . now," he mumbled, as if he was convincing himself. "It's . . . okay . . . now . . . I can . . . rest now . . ."
I'm sorry. I'm sorry.

I shouldn't have done that. To save three people, I killed a hundred. I feel disgusted with myself yet I still feel a little relieved that my family is safe. Maybe I am turning into a monster. Like those green-eyed criminals.
I don't know what to do anymore. I should've killed myself the moment they have found me. Now I can't even decide for my life.
Please, somebody, please end my misery.
"Don't worry too much," she said while wiping off the tears on her eyes and face. "I will be okay."
She smiled while pointing at the tree behind us. "I have a business there."
"I wish I can stay here a bit longer," she mumbled while looking at those two.
I can't. You know that I only stayed here because of my personal matters.
"I've been staying here for more than a year, and honestly, I have enjoyed my time here that I almost forgot I have a life outside this campus."

"I know that sending off a friend is hard, even unbearable for some," he said and I don't know if my eyes were just playing tricks on me but I could see the sadness on his face. "But there are times that you have to."
"Well, I guess this is goodbye," she said.
"Well, I'll be returning the name Kana since it's only an alternative name, but you can still call me that," she said.
"Besides fragrance, one of the kanjis means flowing and living," he explained. "You should live your life and let your time flow from now on."
"I like that," she remarked as she extended her hand to him. "I'll miss our fights."

It's been more than a decade since that dreadful night. Seeing my parents die in front of me was enough to give me nightmares every single day, but what I regretted the most was failing to protect my sister.
"Do you think Mom and Dad are okay?" six-year old Krystal would ask every time there were commotions outside our house.
I would force a smile and say, "of course. They are strong. Really strong."
"Don't worry. If anything happens, I'll protect you with all my life and I'll always be by your side. Is that okay with you?"
She would nod enthusiastically and during those moments, I felt assured. At least, I had her with me. I wasn't alone.
But all of that was taken away from me.
Winter, protect your sister. Will you promise me that?
"I am Winter Alveria," I said as I tightened my grip on his neck. "The head of the Alveria family. And someday, I will take back everything your kin has stolen from me."
"N-no . . . p-please don't k-kill . . ."
"It's time to end the raging flame," I declared as I raised my arm. "Fellow Huntres, let us reclaim what is rightfully ours!"
"Krystal!" I called, my heart racing, afraid that something had happened to her.
"No, please no," I muttered between my sobs. "Krystal . . ."

My heart felt like it was being ripped apart. I never cried when I was with her. I wanted to show her that I could protect her . . . that I was strong. But today, everything that I wanted to keep, that I wanted to protect, was taken away from me.
"I will take back everything," I muttered under my breath as I walked away from the pillar of flames. "I promise."
"But they killed my parents!" he wailed as he gripped his knife tightly turning his knuckles white.

"I have a sister who's almost the same age as you and I failed to protect her," I said in my mind but what surprised me was when I felt the boy flinching. Did he hear that? "I don't want to feel that pain again."
Two years had already passed yet I could still vividly remember how they were killed by Pierre.
"Those with Wind attributes could manipulate the air around, creating some superior mirages," he chuckled. "Nandito na tayo."
Chills began creeping through my body as I watched their eyes changed into different colors: brown, purple and crystal-blue.
"Honestly, no," I answered. "I'm still bewildered. I don't know what to do. I'm not even sure if I really deserve to be here. And . . ."
"Oh. So you can already use your inner voice. Impressive." Isaz was looking at me, a subtle smile escaped from his lips. "Your will is strong, but your body has to keep up."
"Why did you leave me? Why did you not come back for me?"
Dreaming about my sister with that kind of expression on her face was heart-wrenching.
He started walking away and it was painful to watch how slowly he was moving.
"Are you raising your voice at me?" she asked, though it sounded like a warning.
That day, Hilda became the most terrifying person for me.
I shuddered upon seeing his grin. "N-nothing. I . . . I wasn't . . . I mean, I didn't—"
"Why are they doing that?" I asked, seething in anger.
"I'm glad that you're still alive, Leo," he said.
"I . . . I'm sorry," Leo grimaced.
"Minerva . . . she's already dead," he said, his voice trembling. "She sacrificed herself to save us from that terrifying flame."
She said she doesn't want her child to live the same way. She wants her to live normally. And even though I know that's impossible, I want to honor her wish.

He flashed a melancholic smile. "He said he failed to protect your father, our master. He's the type of guy who shoulders everything. But don't worry. I'm sure that when the right time comes, he'll be with us."
"I'm still not sure if it's her," he said, "but I want to continue watching over her."
"Fellow Huntres," I called. "I am Winter Alveria, son of Ark, descendant of Lord Ivankov and Lady Yllka. In the name of our ancestors, I promise, winter will come and this inferno will end soon."
"Halt, Winter," Riyo ordered, his tone quite dangerous. That was when I realized I had already frozen half of the shack's interior.
"They are wrong," she muttered. "I . . . I d-don't want to see that anymore."
"O-our eldest sister . . . s-she pleaded Allen to stop burning villages in the South . . . but that monster," she choked back her tears.
trying not to sound shaken but it was quite evident, "h-he burned her to crisp."
Just then, a quick smile escaped his lips, something I didn't expect to see from him. "After all, you are the rightful leader of the Huntres tribe, Lady Winter."
"But it worked!" he beamed.
"And I already know that she's really my sister." A wistful yet pained smile appeared on his face. "Kelsey is . . . Kelsey is alive and safe."
"Hey, you in the cloak!" he yelled. "Are you an old lady? C'mere you hag!"
"This is all your fault," he hissed.
"W-what happened?" I weakly asked, as I clung to Dalan's arm.
"T-they didn't freeze. They just exploded into snow," he softly said. "You, Lady Winter, reduced them to nothing."
I glared at him and almost wanted to freeze him right on the spot. I wished Hale was here. At least I could control that kid.
"Isaz," I called, my voice trembling, "please . . . help her. I don't want . . . I don't want to lose her again."
"I will," he said. "Don't worry, I will take care of her."
"It's time to start this war," I declared. "Inform all our allies. In a few months, we will attack the White Division. We will reclaim what's ours and I will end this tragic fire."
"Mom, Dad," I whispered as I stared at the only family photo we had. "I can finally avenge your death."
"If you can kill me." I stomped my right foot and the flame surrounding him froze. "And now, I will take back everything you have stolen from me."
"Fellow comrades and allies!" I roared as I glared at Pierre.
"I will do everything to reclaim our place, our honor and the peace between the Huntres' divisions," I seethed, "even if it means killing you and your followers."
"Don't underestimate my fire, brat."
"Don't die. Please."
"I'm sorry . . . Glace,"Dad groaned. "G-go away and find our daughters. P-protect them."
"It's over . . ." I mumbled. "Mom . . . Dad . . . it's over . . ."

"If anything happens, I'll protect you with my life and I'll always be by your side. I'm sorry," I said as my voice cracked. "I'm sorry breaking my promise. I'm sorry for leaving you all alone. Please forgive me."
"So, how did you meet them?" I asked and her eyes twinkled.
"I'm sorry but I also have another family waiting for me."
"Don't you know how to knock?" she growled.
And for the first time, I flashed a smile in front of a huge crowd.
"We're finally home," I softly said.
This time, I felt contentment and not anger.
His bloodshot eyes looked at me with concern while Jett continued fiddling with his guns.
The mood instantly went down after mentioning her name. I felt a pang of guilt and anger when I remembered what happened to her during the battle with Nox.
As a Keeper, I was supposed to keep my team safe but she almost died because of my shortcomings.
I never believed in gods but for the first time, I silently prayed. I just wanted to see her awake and okay before I go.
I was about to go to the bathroom but I received a message from Commander Priam so I immediately went to his office.
"Agent Naia," he called. "Are you sure you can handle this?"

I nodded without a second thought. Only the leaders of the tribes have the authority to enter Shima from the outside but his hands were full with the aftermaths of the Nox's downfall. As someone who had lived there for quite some time, he asked me to bring the criminals to that place.
Truthfully, I was a bit surprised that he knew my past.
When I first arrived here, I was sure I modified my background to prevent them from knowing my connections with Shima. I was just thankful that he didn't ask anything about it.
"There are too many executives for you to escort and it will be too risky for you to handle them alone. Hence, this."
I stared at the device in awe. Senshins and Custos were really stepping up their game in this field.
"Good luck and come back alive," he said and I saluted.
I was admiring the device as I walked to my room when I saw a figure standing on the doorway.
"What? Do you want me to check that?" I asked while pointing at the pistol on his waist band.
Jett quietly followed me as I entered my room and he remained standing while I sat on the side of my bed.
"You're really going alone," he softly said. "Yeah. Alone," I emphasized.
Even though Cliff and Jett didn't say it out loud before, I knew they wanted to come with me, but it would be hard to travel with outsiders. I didn't want to risk their lives.
"No," I firmly said. "You won't last a minute there."
In a splitsecond, the tip of my sword came in contact with his neck and he stood still, a trickle of sweat running down his face.
"If you can't even defend yourself against that, then no."
"that's unfair," he complained. "I wasn't prepared."
I sheathed my sword and smiled at him. "The unprepared are the first to die," I said as I picked up my luggage. "Don't miss me too much."
I was ready to leave my room but halted when I heard him call my name.
"Naia." Turning around, I caught the pistol he just threw at my direction. "Keep safe." A smile escaped my lips upon hearing that line.
I'm a Keeper, I said. "I need to stay alive to keep my team from dying."
The smile on my face faded as I marched away from the place that sheltered me since I was young. It's time to return to the place of curses and chaos.
I had lost track of time as I drifted for days in the middle of the ocean. Fortunately, my supplies were still enough and the ocean was calm
Nel would surely be awake by now. I could imagine her angry face, questioning Cliff and Jett about me.
A smile escaped my lips as I reminisced the life I had in CIA. It was never easy but it was less troubling than where I was headed.
Shima had been a subject of myths and rumors among Erityians. Many believed it was not real, until he met his demise.
I could still remember that time, Executioners were ready to slaughter every Shinigami they had imprisoned, not minding the repercussions from the administration and the council.
Ise, then head of the Jikko clan, vowed to kill every single Shinigami who made his grandson suffer.
"Naia, you should never allow anyone to read your mind," Vince would always say when I was a child.
"Because they can use your thoughts and memories against you."
I heaved a sigh. It's been more than a decade since he died yet the pain still lingered inside me. I missed him.
My thoughts returned to the present when the clear sky and water suddenly turned dark. In a span of a few seconds, everything was already covered in fog.
A wave of nostalgia hit me as I felt the fog brushed against my skin.
As if on cue, the fog dissipated and the familiar island came into view. The silence I was enjoying a while ago was replaced by cries and screams of agony and pain..
The air was filled with metallic and putrid smell—the scent of bloodshed and death.
I smirked. "Yeah. I thought you've already forgotten me."
A guy clad in black holding a huge scythe appeared in front of me. He still looked the same except for the additional creases on his face.
Farallon was never fazed with anything. Even when Vince brought her here, he remained inexpressive.
When Vince died, his face was expressionless but his eyes were gleaming with wrath.
Seeing him after a long time made me feel like I was a kid again.
How's everyone? I asked as I came ashore.
Why are you here? he questioned without answering mine.
Despite his skepticism, he walked with me toward the forest. I heard the familiar roars of Shira and Hyora, the guardians and first line of defense of this island.
"Hey," I snickered as the lion and leopard made their way to me.
I didn't have any friends of my age in this place and all the Executioners were busy with their jobs and missions so I befriended these two.
Among the natives of this island, only me and Aristus could snuggle with these deadly predators.
"Everything has changed here," Farallon said as we passed through the forest.
It was always dark in the woods as the canopy of trees blocked the sunlight.
I remembered getting lost here when I was young and Farallon found me in a critical state.
My arms accidentally brushed against the leaves of a poisonous plant and rendered me motionless.
The venomous insects buzzed around and the deadly plants' leaves fluttered in the wind.
It took us a while to get out of the forest and the stretch of sludge came into view.
Farallon wounded himself, his blood trickling from his finger and it dropped onto the boulder at the forest's threshold.
The rancid smell was enough to make someone nauseous but it was already normal for the inhabitants of this island.
Some Executioners halted, others took a glance at me, as I walked beside Farallon. The older ones were able to recognize me as the child who had red eyes.
"Naia?" One of the called. "Is that you, Naia?"
"Yuma," I replied. "You look old now."
He drew his sword and I swiftly fended off his attack. Some Executioners gathered around, bellowing and cheering, as the two of us were caught in an onslaught.
He was still fast and agile despite his age. I could feel the cuts on my skin, blood streaming through my arms. I managed to land a gash on his cheeks and he looked more excited.
"Damn, child, you better not underestimate me," he beamed as he charged at me.
That moment, my skin tingled as I felt an intense bloodlust from him.
"The unprepared are the first to die."
I remembered what I told to Jett and cursed myself for being too softhearted. This was Shima, a place where comrades could kill one another without giving a thought.
He disappeared from my sight, and the next thing I knew, the tip of his blade was already piercing through my right shoulder.
I gritted my teeth in pain and held his sword.
I kicked his neck as I my hands bled while gripping his blade.
The force made him lose his balance and grip on the sword and I immediately pulled it out of my flesh.
Yuma sat up and laughed hysterically as he looked at me.
Shit, this is bad, he chuckled. "I want to kill you now."
He was ready to charged at me but everyone suddenly fell silent. I felt the immense pressure in the atmosphere, making my body tremble in fear.
W-what was that? I mumbled.
Amidst the silence, I heard heavy footsteps approaching our direction. The Executioners gave way and I saw a hooded man walking toward us.
The tattered cloak fluttered as the wind howled. Behind him was a woman who was eerily familiar. Then I remembered Nel's story about a Senshin who had the eyes of a Shinigami and a Custos.
As far as I remembered, Lionel should be the de-facto leader since Ise lost his only heir when Vince died. I was sure Lionel didn't look like that when I left Shima.
"Child, state your name," he demanded and I flinched upon hearing his voice.
"I see. The child of Diona and Heron," he said and my stomach churned in distress as I heard my parents' names.
He carefully removed his hood and I almost got paralyzed by his stare. Intense and cold green eyes looked right into mine.
"W-who are you?" I asked, my voice shaking in fear.
He bellowed in laughter as if my question was something funny.
"A Jikko branch clan member," he responded. "That old fart didn't even talk to me until he needed someone to inherit his position."
Some Executioners were visibly uncomfortable after hearing him badmouthing Ise. I, too, felt annoyed as Ise was the most respectable person in this island.
"I vowed to hunt down every single Shinigami but they locked me up in this place"
He seethed and I had to step back because his anger screamed danger.
"Damn that council of old and coward shitheads."
"Dad, calm down," the woman behind him softly said.
It had been three hours since I arrived in Shima yet I had already learned about what happened here after Ise and Vince died.
Shira snuggled me and I could hear the guttural sound he was making, as if asking some attention.
Man, you haven't change at all, I snickered while caressing his mane.
I stayed at the shore of the island as they decide what to do with me and the prisoners I had to transfer using the Senshins and Custos technology.
Heaving a sigh, I stared at the endless sea.
I reached for my weapon as I turned my head around and saw that girl. Speaking of the devil.
She walked toward my direction and Shira started snarling at her.
Calm down, boy, I said.
The girl sat beside me and looked at the gray sky. She smiled and it felt so genuine that I let my guard down for a second.
"You know, when I first arrived here, I thought I was going to die. This time, for real"

"I, too, was bringing criminals from the Nox and Sir Hideo told me that I should brace myself when I set foot here. I thought it was because of this island's reputation. I thought it was because of this island's reputation."
She glanced at me and her eyes were so distracting. Her iridescent irises where beautiful and nauseating at the same time.

"I was attacked by the Executioners the moment I landed. I was a fighter, too, but their strength were on a different level. It felt like I was fighting a Huntres with an instinct of a Senshin. It was terrifying."
My lips curved upward. Hearing that compliment for the Jikko clan was uplifting.
"My plan was to leave the criminals, deliver a news, and go back to Tantei High, but everything changed when their leader came to meet me."
"It must be shocking," I commented.
She chuckled in response. "Not really. My Dad is strong and stubborn so deep in my heart, I knew he was still alive, despite being labeled as missing in the records of the Senshins."
The only ones we were told to be wary about in the Senshin tribe were the remnants of the Great Seven, and some of the professors.
"But I didn't expect to see him here. Dad never liked positions."
"Well, he's still a Jikko," I said. "And when . . . when Vince died, the main family had no heir to replace him as the future leader."
I glanced at her, my brows furrowed, unsure if I heard that right.
Huh? What do you mean?
That name triggered a certain memory. I remembered the woman Vince brought here when she returned for a while. It was just a brief time but she was the first friend I had.
I stifled a gasp upon hearing that. Vince and Nathalie? They . . . they had a child?
Where are the criminals you are talking about? he asked, but it sounded like a demand.
Maintaining my composure was difficult in front of this Kyo. His presence was enough to feel his superiority and strength.
There were still pools of blood on the ground and vultures were quietly looming above us. Some of the Executioners were preparing a huge pot of boiling oil and setting up several bamboo stakes.
"Who's going to be tortured?"
The look on their faces was a mixture of nausea, confusion and anger
Despite their feet and hands being bound, few of them started attacking the people around . . . which was a wrong and dumb move.
"This one's mine!"
"Humdrums are, indeed, stupid."
"Couple of Erityians, too."
"How does that feel?" Yuma taunted as he pointed his scythe to an Executive neck. "Your members are being toyed by an 11-year old Jikko."
"A traitor like you," Yuma said as the tip of his scythe digging through Eerie's skin, "brings shame to the Senshin tribe."
My skin crawled upon hearing that familiar voice and when I turned around, I saw Lionel walking toward our direction.
"I have finished cleaning the Rei level," he reported to Kyo.
"Good," Kyo responded and Lionel went to the Nox's direction. "Reliable as ever," he commented.
"Of course," I said. "He's been Vince's rival since they were young. Strength wise, he's probably second to you."
"You're right," he chuckled. "But potential-wise, that brat is higher than him."
I shuddered when I felt his presence getting stronger and I had to step back to not get overwhelmed. When I looked at him, his grin was nowhere to be found and it was replaced with a grim expression.
"Okay. I'll be counting on you."
He silently walked away and I was left alone. I wanted to contact the CIA but communication outside was forbidden in this island.
It's been 36 hours since I arrived here and I was still adjusting to the intensity of voices inside my head.
My range had improved and I could now hear the cries and howls in the prisons. It was draining but I was used to this kind of exhaustion since I was a child.
I suddenly remembered how Nathalie almost lost her memories before because of these voices.
That must be really scary.
Hearing a voice inside my head, which was neither a scream of pain nor cries from mind torture, made me flinch. Who . . . wait . . .
Nathalie looked at my direction, a hint of surprise on her face, but after a few seconds, she smiled, as if she had finally recognized me.
Then my eyes drifted to the guy beside him and I halted when I saw his face.
"This pisses me off," Kyo grumbled. "It's like looking at those two brats' faces."
Nathalie chuckled. "I know what you mean, Sir Kyo. Well, Hideo raised him so he kinda got his personality."
"You kid," he said while looking at the guy.
Wow. He's got guts. I'll give him that.
Kyo grinned as if he just found someone to toy with.
"Too much noise."
"You probably should not stay here," I said and he looked at me. "Seems like you have the same ability as Nathalie."
That was the first time I saw someone greatly affected by the thoughts and inner voices of people despite our capability to block them.
"You can hear inner voices despite their closed minds, right?" He nodded.
"You sure you can handle the agony and pain of the tortured? The heinous and brutal thoughts of the prisoners? The radical ways and thoughts of the executioners?"
He winced before he could answer my questions. I knew it. Those voices must be causing a discomfort and pain on his mind.
I stared at him for a few seconds. I wasn't sure if he was confident or just foolish.
Amid the silence, I could hear faint voices, screams of agony and desperation from the prisoners.
Within a splitsecond, I drew my sword and swung it to his direction.
Shock and confusion came into his face, and he leapt back, avoiding a serious cut on his neck. I pulled back my sword and looked at him.
"Seems like your flight instincts have been honed," I remarked as blood trickled from his neck.
"But, kiddo, Jikkos are known for fighting, not evading. I guess you aren't ready to inherit that name yet."
My words seemed to struck a chord and the look on his eyes instantly changed.
I was caught off-guard for a second because he looked exactly like Vince when he's pissed.
"Kiddo? You seem like just a few years older than me," he commented.
"I call everyone weaker than me a kiddo," I retorted, and somehow it felt good.
I didn't know taunting someone who could talk back would be this entertaining since Jett and Cliff would always give up before I could enjoy the conversation.
Before his hand could reach for something behind him, I lunged at him and gripped his arm.
I snatched his gun as he fell on his back and pointed it at him. I fired two bullets on each side of his head, just a few inches from his ears.
"What? Did you life flash right before your eyes?" I taunted.
A smile escaped my lips as I remembered how they described Vince's death.
I felt an intense pressure behind us and when I turned around, Kyo and Nathalie was already walking toward our direction.
I glanced at the guy who just got up and kept glaring at me. "He'd lose to Karim," I replied.
"Too slow. Too weak. Too emotional. Too self-centered. If I'm an Executioner, I won't offer my trust and loyalty to someone who can't even defend himself."
Kyo bellowed in laughter while Nathalie looked conflicted.
That kid's presence was overwhelming, maybe the most intense among the Executioners besides Kyo, but that wouldn't mean anything if his body couldn't keep up.
"No filters and sugarcoating, huh? I like that," Kyo commented.
I scoffed. "I don't like toning down my words. A weak must know he's weak, otherwise, he'd be complacent."
"Naia . . ." Nathalie called, a look of worry flashed on her face.
"I'm sorry, Nathalie. I'm just saying the truth. Well then, I need to rest."
I started walking away from them. Kyo was still chuckling but the two remained silent.

My words might be harsh but this place is harsher. His naivety would just cause more harm. If it was the other Executioners that challenged him, he'd be dead by now. He should have prepared himself before setting foot here.
I was on my way to my cabin when I saw Aristus standing near it. "Aristus!" I called as I ran toward his direction.
He smiled upon seeing me. "Naia."
"I just learned that you're here," he softly said. "And also Nathalie . . . and his son."
"I arrived yesterday and you just heard it today?" I noted as I squinted my eyes. "How many days did you spend inside your cave this time?"
He chuckled nervously. "Uh, a week, I think?"
"Learning and writing our history is fun. You should try it," he remarked as his eyes twinkled in excitement.
His enthusiasm about it made me retch. Aristus is the weakest here in terms of physical abilities, but the Executioners respect his vast knowledge about our race.
Aristus smirked and glanced at the isolated part of the island, which was called blood chamber, because of the red-dyed ground due to the volcano and keimusho.
"Still as persuasive as ever, huh?"
Despite closing my mind, I could still hear voices inside my head as we got nearer.
Nathalie and Hiro would probably lose their minds the moment they stepped into this chamber.
The temperature in this place took up a notch and I started sweating profusely.
I already took off my coat and tied my hair but Aristus seemed unaffected. How could he still look comfortable with that mantle covering his body? Damn monster.
I breathed deeply and willed myself to stay calm. "Yeah. It's just . . . it's been a while since I last went here."
It became hotter as we descended and it felt like my skin and bones would just melt.
I could also hear the screams and cries of the prisoners and it made my head throb in pain.
Blood was splattered across his face and his blonde hair was dyed with scarlet hues. His green eyes gleamed in the dimly lit space and my skin crawled when he smiled at us.
"Ah. I just finished questioning this one," he said as he lifted the guy by grabbing his hair.
"That's good," Aristus commented. "I need more information."

I shuddered upon hearing his words. Dale was an elusive target, even for us, yet he was already thinking of how he could make his life miserable.
This guy . . . he might be more frightening than Kyo. And those two are the current main force of the Jikko clan. I wonder if that kid could hold a candle to them.
"Really?" I muttered as Farallon readied the boat
"That's the rule, kid," he said. "You can't communicate with others within the island."
I was left alone in the middle of the sea and I realized there was a brewing storm nearby.
"Damn it," I muttered while getting the device the Commander gave me.
"Naia," he greeted. "Good to hear from you. What happened?"
"The criminals have been transferred successfully, Commander," I reported.
Farallon still couldn't believe that those beasts could still remember me and I was the only one that could cuddle them.
"I heard you went to the blood chamber with Aristus," he said and my body almost trembled when I remembered what happened there.
"Yeah. It was like coming back from hell."
He snickered. "Right. Remember when you first went there? Vince had to get you away from that place because it triggered your eyes."

Ise said I wasn't allowed to be in the blood chamber because I was still too young and weak, but I wanted to see it. Besides, I admire both Vince and Lionel, even vowing to be their apprentice, but they both dismissed me.
Fortunately, Ise had already taught me how to conceal my presence and both of their attention were on the criminals so it was quite easy for me to follow..
I thought I was doing a good job, until something happened
I heard voices, several of them, crying and howling in agony and pain.
My head felt like it would burst any minute.
When I was in the island, I never heard those voices that loud but upon stepping onto the blood chamber, I realized why they never allowed those who hadn't trained yet.
It slowed me down but I thought I could control my mind. However, something made it much more complicated.
The next thing I knew, he was already grinning menacingly at my direction. Everything happened so fast that I only realized my situation when I was already held by my neck.
As a kid, I was beyond terrified. The prisoner took me as a hostage.
My neck was pressed between his chest and arms as my body dangled. The tip of the knife was digging through my cheeks and blood began to trickle down my face.
I was terrified and I felt something was changing in my mind and body.
Colors flickered in my irises and I saw a lot of people getting slaughtered and skinned by the knife that was poking me.
Fear coursed through my body, not because of my situation, but because of Vince and Lionel.
Their eyes gleamed malevolently as they swung their scythes in the air.
"Get her out of here," Lionel seethed as he looked at the rest of the prisoners who were as terrified as I was.
Vince immediately carried me and I remembered crying because he got angry at me.
Wow. I couldn't believe that was already a long time ago," I said as I smiled, remembering Vince's life before he went away and died.
"Yeah. And now all we have is his skinny brat."
"Can this be used in, say, a fight against a Shinigami?" he asked but before Aristus could reply, Farallon was already charging at their direction.
"Yes it can, brat," he said. "this blade has been bathed by Shinigamis' blood since it was made."
"Yes, that's his real attitude. He only acts quiet to look like Lionel but the truth is he's a lot more savage than Vince."
"Naia," she called. "Sorry if I wasn't able to talk to you."
"But I'm glad I got to see you again."
She smiled. "I will, Sir."
"You rascal, you're really his son."
"Let's go back," he ordered and the pressure of his presence was so heavy that I felt like my knees would buckle.
It seems like we'll get a lot of prisoners in the coming days.
That moment, I realized the Erityian race was slowly shifting . . . but I don't know if it's for the better or worse.
After visiting the blood chamber, the voices I heard kept echoing inside my head.
I was itching to fight someone
By nightfall, everything in the island was already engulfed in darkness.
Hearing that voice made me shudder.
My hands instinctively reached my sword and swung it at the presence behind me.
Blood splattered on my face and on the floor, stunned to see Kiyoko's smiling face.
That made me chuckle since that was quite true. Being eccentric and radical is the normal here

"Yeah." A hint of sadness flashed across her face.
"And you know furious they are at them."
Vince's face zoomed inside my head and how the rest of the Jikko clan acted when they received the news of his death.
"Because of what happened, they even harbor resentment to Hideyoshi and the administration," she continued.
"Ise completely cut the communication between them because trusting them cost him his grandson's life."
My heart almost sank upon hearing Ise's name. I grew up with Vince and Ise was particularly strict on him.
He would always say that he should never lose a fight because that's a disgrace as a Jikko.
She smiled. "Yup. Apparently, he sneaked out of this island when he was a teenager because if he stayed, he'd be named as the chief of the village."
Although some of my memories were hazy, I remembered Ise getting furious when a letter suddenly arrived from the outside.
Yeah. The fate he wanted to avoid caught up to him. I guess he was really meant to lead this clan before the true heir steps in.
My nerves finally calmed down after talking to Kiyoko. I was grateful that she came here.

My breath caught in my throat as I stared at her. It didn't even occur to me that she didn't have any idea about what happened to team Magnus. Her eyes looked at me expectantly and I felt awful after remembering his last moments.
"I . . . I'm sorry," I mumbled, my voice trembling.

Her expression tightened and before I could explain anything, she had already averted my gaze. I could feel an overwhelming pressure from her presence and I willed myself not to step back even though it was getting suffocating
Kiyoko started walking away without a word. I heaved a sigh, worried about what she would do. Nel said Kiyoko was nice and sweet but her expression a while ago was far from that.
My body automatically reacted to his presence, jumping back and assuming a defensive stance. Kyo burst out laughing after seeing what I did.

He cackled. "Reds are so hard to persuade."

A subtle smile appeared on my lips. "I think so, too. But I prefer this kind of life now."

"What an arrogant brat you are."

There was a few seconds of silence and it looked like they were planning something.
After our encounters with the Nox, Nel was becoming more and more like a captain.
Well, I couldn't sleep the whole time I was there and staying there was mentally draining, I wanted to say but I just smiled instead.
Before I could explain how far I was from Romania, she had already ended the call. That freaking girl. Did she just cut me off? Damn it. I'm going to break her bones once I get there.
But . . . I didn't expect I'd miss their voices that much. I couldn't wait to be with them again.
It felt strange to be alone in this still and silent ocean after staying for days in Shima
An hour later, I received a holographic call from Cliff. His face flickered in front of me, and even though the quality wasn't good, I could see the horror on his expression.
He drew a shaky breath and I realized he was still gripping the seatbelt tightly. "We're going to die."

Cliff was on the passenger's seat, horrified as the car seemed to accelerate.
Nel looked thrilled after days of being confined.

It turned out I needed at least three days to go there so in the end, I couldn't participate.
Well, she said they could only bring two companions so I guess she really didn't need me to be there.

"Be careful. There are Shinigami and Nox bases in Europe."
I was still in the middle of the Pacific Ocean and it would take me a day to reach Japan. Fortunately, my devices were working well.
Fortunately, everyone seemed to be humdrums. "It's safe," I concluded.
My lips curved up, remembering their terrified expression a few hours ago.
Want me to carry you? Cliff asked, chuckling. "Kiddi—!" Before he could even tell he was just joking, Nel was already climbing on his back.
Jett started walking, maybe afraid that Nel might do that to him, too.
"See that yellow tree over there?" I said, raising my voice.
Something's written here, Jett remarked and I told Nel to look at the boulder.
They followed the direction but they halted when the path ended with a cave. "Should we enter this?" asked Cliff.
It took them thirty minutes to finally find the exit, but before I could see it, the connection was cut. I couldn't hear nor see anything.
"Hello? Nel? Cliff? Jett?" Nothing. I tried calling them again but to no avail. They weren't responding
For a second, I was worried, thinking that they got buried before they could leave the cave.
I threw my device on the raft and heaved a sigh. I wanted to know what was going on but there were no ways to contact them anymore.
I just hope they are safe.
"Yeah. That kid is cool."
Nel was too excited to tell me what happened during the meeting of the four tribes.
Honestly, I didn't expect it to be successful because of the Shinigami tribe.
Neo-classical buildings, museums and monuments were scattered all over the city. It felt like I was pulled back in the medieval period because of the architecture and arts around me.
He went inside the building and vanished from my sight.
Every step I took echoed through the room. When I arrived at the central hall, I almost got decapitated.

They all lunged at me, their weapons ranging from blades to blunt to guns.
My mind was suddenly filled with angry and agonizing voices, as if I was back in Shima.

Within a minute, the only one left was the first guy who discovered me. His hands were trembling as he pointed his sword at my direction.
Before he could take a step backward, my sword had already pierced his throat.
"Hi," I greeted.
They didn't greet me back. Instead, they seethed in rage as they saw the scarlet floor where their lifeless comrades were.
I was about to make the first move but I halted when I saw people coming behind them.
My blood ran cold when I saw two children, a girl and a boy and maybe about seven to ten years old, stood in front of them, their eyes vacant of feelings.
I drew a deep breath trying to calm myself but seeing those two made it difficult.
A wave of fury stirred in my chest as they commanded the children to attack me.
My heart tightened as both of them lurched at me.
When I looked at the two kids, they crumbled down on their knees and collapsed.
I let my rage control me.
With my sword bathed in blood, I slashed everyone at every direction.
Cursing them inside my head after what they did to those children.

When I looked around, a shiver went down my spine.
Nel looked horrified as he stared at the bloodbath but her expression softened when he saw the two kids lying unconscious on the floor.
I heaved a sigh as lifeless bodies in a pool of blood surrounded me.
I smiled at them. "Sorry, I can't be a good Keeper."
With my remaining strength, I walked at their direction. Finally, we were together again.
After what had happened in Romania, they seemed to be more nervous around me.
I had been suppressing my Executioner instinct since I left the island a few days ago, vowing not to let my emotions control me, but I lost it during the mission.
I had been seeing those flashes since I first held this gun, which was several years ago already, but they still bothered me every time.

"You look dangerous even without any weapon. Don't you know how scary you are?"
I failed to suppress a smile after hearing that from him.

"His expression darkened."
I could feel the tension on his shoulders as he continued playing with his pistol.

I heaved a sigh and smiled

"Well, I was raised . . . differently, so I didn't know how to act in front of people."
I couldn't continue what I was going to say because of the sudden turbulence. A holograph flickered on the windows of the plane and Commander's face appeared in front of us.
"Team Optimus, well done," he said, "but I have another mission for you and this takes priority."
The four of us exchanged looks and nodded. "Roger!"
His face flickered and disappeared after sending the message. The air was suddenly filled with tension

Jett and I exchanged nervous looks
My mouth hung open when I saw two figures scrunched down the floor. Zeno and Dale were bloodied, just like the rest of the Executives.
Von had visible gunshots on his shoulders and leg but he didn't seem to mind them. Fenn had it worse. He had deep cuts on his hands and a long gash from his right to left cheek.
That was a lot dangerous than the headgear invented by the Senshins. But to contain the Nox leaders, I guess they had to take risks, especially against their dangerous animus.
Dale could turn invisible for a few seconds and Zeno could paralyze the nerves of a person using his blood.
"This marks the end of Nox," Von said as he looked at Dale with a pained expression.

I'm sure they were still affected since they grew up with him. They were his team, his comrades, but he betrayed them because of his vision and beliefs. Fighting him must have been hard for them. "Let's go home," Yue said
We started leading them to our aircraft, our feet heavy with burden and responsibilities
Nox has created hatred toward humdrums and vilified their existence.

After his speech, he informed them the Executives were currently resting due to the injuries they got.
He also gave new missions to the teams present and said he would be counting on them.
For the first time in a long time, I relaxed my mind after putting up walls to protect my thoughts.
"Why can't he be a normal leader?" she grumbled.
Silence filled the room. She must be also exhausted after our mission.

I sat up groggily and pulled my device from my pocket and there was a message from the Commander.
"I assume you already know why you're here," he said
With what had transpired before the capture of Dale and Zeno, I already had an idea about what he wanted me to do. My expression hardened
"Yes, Sir," I answered.
He looked at me with his intense red eyes and it felt like seeing the Blood Chamber from them.
Commander's face darkened. "The cells will disintegrate once it gets teleported. The headgears will weaken them, but I doubt it would stop them once they resist its effect."
She raised her eyebrow. "I thought we have a mission?"
I must have looked really confused because they all started snickering at me.
"What the heck are you talking about?"
"Slow down," Cliff said with gritted teeth.

If I were on my right mind, I would have laughed, but Nel's speed was just making me more distressed.

Nel sped up and both of them cursed as they cried for their lives.
I could still see the scars on her arms and I remembered how she almost died during the fight against the Navis.
She lost her mother for the second time and now she would lose Dale, too

My childhood in Shima was kept a secret and I was grateful that the Commander didn't break his word.
My parents were still considered traitors and I'm sure people wouldn't see me any different if they learned about them.
In times like this, I missed him to the point that it felt like I was back to being a child again.
When I traveled here few weeks ago, I felt alone and restless, not knowing how long I would drift in the middle of nowhere.

But this time, it was kind of calming knowing I had my comrades with me. They wouldn't be probably allowed to enter the island but knowing that the three of them would be mwaiting for me outside was already reassuring enough.
I smiled at them and stole a snack from Jett's supplies.
"Mentally draining, isn't it?" I said while inspecting my sword.
"I can't even imagine how I'm going to survive if I'm alone. How do you even do it?"
The temperature suddenly dropped and the sky turned gray. A swirl of mist and thick fog enveloped our surroundings, obscuring our vision. Each of them assumed a defensive stance, their weapons ready.
I stood at the front of the raft. "We're here." As soon as I said those words, a smaller raft appeared and got wafted to our direction. I turned to them and smiled.
"Sorry. I'm the only one who can go inside."
"Until I return. Don't do anything. Don't look for me. Just stay here and wait."
I stared at Jett and smirked. "You'd be dead before you can do anything."
I could feel the chills crawling onto my skin and I had to keep myself from shivering. The menacing aura was way more intense and blood-chilling than the last time

I chuckled. "Jealous?"
"Shut your mouth," Naia.
"Why are you here, kid?" he asked in a disgruntled tone
I had to choke back the creeping fear on my throat.
"Well, he wants to end this Nox problem as quick as possible."

A burst of light, along with shrapnel shells, exploded, wounding several Executioners but they didn't even budge from where they stood. Two figures appeared; their headgears already destroyed. I drew my sword but before they could even check their surroundings, the curved blades of the scythes were already around their necks.
Kyo chuckled menacingly. "Welcome to my island, traitors."
Lionel asked if I would want to accompany them in the Blood Chamber but I declined. That place wouldn't be good for my state of mind right now.
I almost swung my sword when I heard a voice behind me. Fortunately, Aristus' voice sounded familiar and I was able to restrain myself.
"You know, you almost lost your head," I said as I got my hands off the sheath
"Speaking of that, why is everyone acting weird?"
Before I could hear his explanation, I felt something eerie. My skin tingled and I felt an unfamiliar presence.
The Shinigami felt my presence and drew a dagger.
We exchanged blows, trying to outmaneuver each other, but despite using a shorter blade, he was keeping up with my attacks and speed.
"Who are you?" I grumbled, "and why are you here?"
I thrust my sword and it gashed his right shoulder
I'm the one asking questions, I retorted. "You have no right—"
My knees buckled, as if my strength were being sucked out.
Did he use his sixth sense?
"Stop. Both of you."

"Sorry for the distress I caused," he told Kiyoko.
She smiled. "It's alright. They just can't believe a Shinigami can be different from what they are used to. Though I know a couple of Shinigamis like you."
He, too, smiled upon hearing that.
They exchanged looks and he flashed a subtle smile. "Someone who can turn the tide in the fight between the Shinigami factions."
Darwin bowed at her. "Thank you."
"I know you're mad," said Kiyoko who was looking at the same direction. "I, too, despise the Shinigamis with all my heart."
I, too, wished I could kill every single one of them, especially those who caused Vince's demise. I wanted to avenge him.
She chuckled softly. "I will tell him. Good work on bringing the criminals here. Goodbye, Naia."
She reached for her pocket and she held out the tip of a broken spear. She smiled at me but her eyes showed concern.
My heart almost sank when I realized what it was.
My hands started trembling and it felt like I was a child again.

I winced upon hearing her story and remembered how it happened.
I drew a shaky breath and reached for the spear. The moment my finger touched its blade, a flash of memories flooded my mind.
A Shinigami annihilating a group of humdrums. Heads rolling on the ground. A dungeon where Shinigamis get tortured. A girl whose green eyes were seething with hatred . . .
"Are you okay?" Kiyoko asked with a worried tone."Y-yes," I weakly said. "I'm . . . I'm okay. Thank you for this."
"Naia," she called. "Say hello to Nel for me." I will.
Do you know how difficult it is to keep these two from entering the island?
"What?" I asked
What's wrong with them?
They're just worried about you. You spent almost three hours there.
Heh. When did you guys become so clingy? "I am not clingy," Nel retorted. "It's just that this place is giving me the creeps."
"She's right," Jett added.
I already told you that this place isn't normal. Oh well, we're leaving.
"I'm glad you're safe," Nel suddenly said, breaking the silence. I . . . I really thought you're not coming back to us.
I looked at her, but she kept her gaze in front of her
A smile escaped my lips. "I'm a Keeper," I said. "I need to stay alive and safe to keep my team from dying."

"Whoa, careful!" Cliff cried as he tried to balance the raft. "Nel, you're crushing her," Jett commented. "Yeah. You're a Keeper so please don't do anything dangerous, or else, we'll die," she muttered, ignoring the guys' comments.
I chuckled and patted her back. "Roger, Captain."
The smile didn't leave my face as we drifted farther away from the place that I once called home
We're going home.
Cries of terror and anguish.Weapons clashing against each other
Naomi's thoughts flooded my mind as Mitsuo collapsed on his knees, refusing to slump on the ground even on his final breath
My heart sank upon seeing two of my friends in the brink of their death.
Ah . . . I think it's time . . .' she muttered.
Mitsuo coughed blood but he remained looking in the sky, the rain falling down his face.

His eyes were already closed but I could still hear his faint voice in my head. Run away, Nathalie,' he mumbled, a smile of resignation on his face. Please don't look back. Save yourself. Save yourself . . . Don't worry . . . I . . . I will always remember you . . . N-Nathalie . . .
"Assist Naomi!" shouted Mayu.

Please be safe.

The Council will surely question their ties and loyalty.

Y-you . . .
